head.supplied: THE UNIVERSITY ¶ ADELAIDE ¶ July 1. 1891 ¶ My dear Baron ¶ ¶ Out of a collection of 29 species gathered by Dr Stirling ¶ between lat 17° & 24° on the Trans-continental Telegraph Line are a few which...

div.p: RB MSS M20, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: MS found with a specimen of Maireana Scleroptera (MEL 42020).

div.p:
Out of a collection of 29 species gathered by Dr Stirling
Edward Charles Stirling. between lat 17° & 24° on the Trans-continental Telegraph Line are a few which offer difficulties for me in the way of their determinations, chiefly because of the paucity of specimens & immature condition of the floral organs.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Kochia n. sp. The horizontal wings in the form of stiff oblong rays.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: A not very satisfactory dissection of one flower seemed to reveal 1-celled ovary with the ovules laterally attached in 2 clusters of 6 to 8.
The two large semidecurrent and unilaterally-disposed bracteoles are prominent characteristics.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Melaleuca n. sp. The stamens are in 5 bundles of about 10, but are very shortly united. The colour of the stamens & the foliage separate it from the other Callistemonoid species. The venulation of the leaf approximates to that of M . leucadendron .

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p: Cyperid. Genus? There seem to be 2 hermaphrodite flowers in each spikelet & flat membranous hypogynous scales to each flower.

div.p:
I have been solicited to present a few notes on the collection to the next meeting of the Royal Society (6th inst.); and as the collection has been in my hands only a few days I have found that in the press of other work and in view of the imperfection of the material representing genera & species unfamiliar to me; I hereby ask your cooperation in respect of the unidentified material.
See M to R. Tate, 5 July 1891. The meeting of the Royal Society of South Australia was held on 7 July, not 6 July, when 'Professor Tate ably described some native plants … collected by Dr Stirling' (South Australian register, 8 July 1891, p. 5). The notes were published in the volume for the following year (Tate (1892)).

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
P.S. The specimens as
are intended?
sent herewith as a postal-parcel.
